<div class="asset-content p402_premium subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<div class="subscriber-preview"><p>WEST FRANKFORT -- The city of West Frankfort has issued a boil water order for all customers in the 22 block area from South Lincoln Street west to the rail road tracks and from East Clark Street south to Forest Street.</p></div><div class="tnt-ads-container text-center hidden-sm hidden-md hidden-lg"><div class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-dfp-adunit="/8438/thesouthern.com/news/local/boil-orders" data-dfp-custom-pos="fixed-big-ad-top, atf" data-dfp-size="[300,250]" id="fixed-big-ad-top-mobile" style="min-height:250px; min-width:300px;"></div></div>
<div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><div class="tnt-ads-container text-center "><div class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-dfp-adunit="/8438/thesouthern.com/news/local/boil-orders" data-dfp-custom-pos="fixed-inline-video, stf" data-dfp-size="[4,1]" data-lazy="true" id="fixed-inline-video" style="min-height:1px; min-width:4px;"></div></div>
<div class="subscriber-preview"><p>The boil order is to replace a water and will be in effect until further notice.</p></div><div class="tnt-ads-container text-center hidden-sm hidden-md hidden-lg"><div class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-dfp-adunit="/8438/thesouthern.com/news/local/boil-orders" data-dfp-custom-pos="fixed-big-ad-middle, stf" data-dfp-size="[300,250]" id="fixed-big-ad-middle-mobile" style="min-height:250px; min-width:300px;"></div></div>
<div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"></div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"></div>
</div>

</div></div></div><script>
        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#tncms-region-asset_side_sticky');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 80;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 80) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#site-footer-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 80);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });
    </script>

<div class="infinity-summary-container hidden-print" id="infinite-container">
<div data-next-url="http://thesouthern.com/tncms/search/mlt/?origin=f75af71d-f507-52a0-9215-455b5958a65e&app=editorial&inline=infinity&type=article%2Ccollection%2Cvideo%2Cyoutube" id="infinite-more">
<i class="fa fa-spinner fa-pulse"></i>
</div>
</div>
<script>
        
            var bFoundOrigin = true;
            var sOriginID = null;
        
        var sOriginURL = scrubURL('http://thesouthern.com/tncms/search/mlt/?origin=f75af71d-f507-52a0-9215-455b5958a65e&app=editorial&inline=infinity&type=article%2Ccollection%2Cvideo%2Cyoutube'); // original url scrubbed for preview
        var sFirstID = null;
        var bFirstRun = true;
        var bShowAd = true;
        var bInfiniStop = false;

        function populateInfinitySet(sURL) {
            sURL = scrubURL(sURL);

            // Until the origin paramter for cms.search.mlt functions, we have to start/stop the looping on our own
            // This will require not displaying any assets until we hit oAsset.
            // Then we loop through and display until we've been through everything up to our origin

            $.ajax(sURL).then(function(oResponse, sStatus, oXHR) {

                var sNextUrl = null;

                if (typeof oResponse.next_url == 'undefined') {
                    // URL supplied is no good. Revert to original URL
                    sNextUrl = sOriginURL;
                } else {
                    sNextUrl = scrubURL(oResponse.next_url);
                }

                // Manage response
                if (typeof oResponse.assets != 'undefined' && oResponse.assets.length > 0) {
                    
                    // Remove old more data
                    $("#infinite-more").remove();

                    
                    // Build infinity set
                    $.each(oResponse.assets, function(index) {
                            if (index == 1 && sOriginID == null) {
                                sOriginID = oResponse.assets[0].id;
                            }
                        // Display assets once origin is found
                        if (bFoundOrigin == true) {
                            if (this.id == sOriginID) {
                                bInfiniStop = true;
                                sNextUrl = null;
                                $("#infinite-more").remove();
                                
                            } else if (bInfiniStop == false && this.id != 'f75af71d-f507-52a0-9215-455b5958a65e') {
                                // Display asset
                                var sHTML = '';
                                if (this.content) {
                                    sHTML += '<div class="infinite-item original row"><div class="col-md-8">' + this.content + '</div><div class="col-md-4 text-center">';
                                    if (bShowAd == true) {
                                        // Show advertisement
                                        sHTML += '<div class="infinity-ad empty"></div>'
                                        bShowAd = false;
                                    } else {
                                        bShowAd = true;
                                    }
                                    sHTML += '</div></div><hr>';
                                }
                            }
                        } else {
                            if (this.id == sOriginID) {
                                // Origin found. Begin displaying assets
                                bFoundOrigin = true;
                            } else {
                                // Origin found is false. Skip asset
                                // Fail-safe in case origin is not present in set. This can be removed when origin is fixed.
                                if (bFirstRun == true) {
                                    // Stored first id
                                    sFirstID = this.id;
                                    bFirstRun = false;
                                } else if (this.id == sFirstID) {
                                    // We've started again. Force origin
                                    sOriginID = sFirstID;
                                    bFoundOrigin = true;
                                } // end Fail-safe
                            }
                        }
                        // Append infinity set to container
                        $("#infinite-container").append(sHTML);
                    });

                    // Include block_id on newly added list items
                    $('#infinite-container .infinite-item.original').each(function() {
                        var sHref = scrubURL($(this).find(".card-headline a").attr("href"));
                        
                        // Add to image and headlines links
                        $(this).removeClass('original')
                            .find(".card-headline a, .image a")
                            .attr("href", sHref + "#tncms-source=infinity-scroll-summary-siderail-latest");
                    });

                    // Check next URL
                    if (sNextUrl) {
                        // if origin hasn't been found yet and we hit next_url. Trigger the set to pull in again.
                        if (bFoundOrigin == false) {
                            // No origin yet. Call the populate function
                            populateInfinitySet(sNextUrl);
                        } else {
                            // Append sNextUrl to infinity set
                            $("#infinite-container").append('<div id="infinite-more" data-next-url="' + sNextUrl + '"><i class="fa fa-spinner fa-pulse"></i></div>');
                        }
                    }
                    
                        // Ad waypoint and handler to insert ads next to summary
                        $('.infinity-ad.empty').waypoint({
                            offset: '80%',
                            handler: function(direction) {
                                // Kill waypoint
                                this.destroy();
                                $(this.element).removeClass('empty');
                                // Create and append ad iframe. Make sure this occurs only once
                                var newIframe = infinityAd();
                                if($(this.element).children().length <= 0) {
                                    $(this.element).append(newIframe);
                                }
                            }
                        });
                    
                    // Refresh waypoints
                    Waypoint.refreshAll();
                } else {
                    // Empty asset set returned. Go back in for a real set
                    populateInfinitySet(sNextUrl);
                }
            });
        }

        // Infinite waypoint
        var waypoint = new Waypoint({
            element: document.getElementById('infinite-container'),
            handler: function(direction) {
                if (direction == 'down') {
                    if (bInfiniStop == true) {                        
                        // FINISHED. Kill the waypoint
                        this.destroy();
                    } else {
                        // Log waypoint hit event
                        __tnt.trackEvent({'category':'infinity-scroll','action':'request', 'label':'assets requested', 'value': true});
                        var nextURL =  $('#infinite-more').data('next-url');
                        populateInfinitySet($('#infinite-more').data('next-url'));
                    }
                }
            },
            offset: 'bottom-in-view'
        });

        // Infinity ad
        function infinityAd() {
            var newIframe = document.createElement('iframe');
            newIframe.scrolling = 'no';
            newIframe.src = 'http://thesouthern.com/tncms/block/1401217/?disableTNStatsTracker=1';
            return newIframe;
        }
        // Rewrite URL to for preview
        function scrubURL(sURL) {
            if (typeof sURL != 'undefined'){
                return sURL;
            }
        }
    </script>

Weather Forecast


Boil water alert issued for Thompson water system

THOMPSON The State Health Department has issued a boil water order for the Cold Spring Road area of the Town of Thompson Water system.

All water for drinking and culinary purposes must be brought to a rolling boil before consuming because coliform bacteria was found in three consecutive samplings on June 16, 18 and 20. The state standard is that no more than one of the samples may be positive.

Whenever coliform bacteria is detected in a sample, follow-up testing is required to determine if other bacteria of greater concern, like E. coli, are present. E. coli was not found in this subsequent testing.

Harmful microbes in drinking water can cause diarrhea, cramps, nausea, headaches or other symptoms.

An alternative to using boiled water is to use bottled water certified for sale in New York.

Boil order lifted early after water plant floods

Posted:

  • WGEM LinksMore>>

  • Hospital makes special arrangements as boil order is lengthened

    Hospital makes special arrangements as boil order is lengthened

    As a boil order for the entire city of Hannibal and its surrounding area extends through Friday, many residents and businesses are making other plans to meet basic needs.More >>
    As a boil order for the entire city of Hannibal and its surrounding area extends through Friday, many residents and businesses are making other plans to meet basic needs.More >>
HANNIBAL, Mo. (WGEM) - Utility officials lifted a boil order Thursday afternoon at 4:20 p.m. for residents in and around Hannibal. The boil order for customers of the Ralls County Public Water Supply district will remain in place until Friday at 1 p.m.

BPW customers and PWSD residents were asked Monday to begin conserving water after the basement in the treatment plant flooded Sunday afternoon. The conservation warning was lifted Wednesday morning at 8 a.m.

Monday afternoon, PWSD and BPW issued a boil order for all customers in the service territories through Wednesday at 1 p.m. That order was extended Tuesday, when officials said the boil order would expire Friday at 1 p.m., but after all bacterial testing came back clear, BPW officials lifted the boil order early.

"Residents are now free to use water as they normally would," Kari Goodman, of BPW said. "However, some customers are experiencing dirty water, so please be mindful when doing laundry."

An update on BPW's website said water levels were back to normal in the water treatment plant and system tanks Wednesday morning.

Places like the Hannibal Nutrition Center, which serves meals to dozens of people a day, had to switch gears fast.

"So anything that we cooked today, we used boiled water on and then for our dinner tonight we're making sure that we even boiled our coffee and tea to make sure we took care of that matter," Executive Director Debbie Catlett said.

Ice was another concern for Catlett. So much so, workers went to a gas station to get enough for the day. Resident Tony Weldy said even he didn't fully understand how much water he used until Monday.

"I do realize it, but I don't realize what all you need clean water for, I guess sometimes, so washing dishes in the dishwasher even or even taking a bath or shower," Weldy said.

BPW Director of Operations Heath Hall still isn't sure how this happened, but the department is already trying to figure out ways to make sure they don't find themselves in this situation again.

"We have several ideas in the works on how to prevent this from happening again, from putting some extra alarms in, to raising the motors up even higher," Hall said. "There are several things in the works, so we're going to try. Many of them very cheap."

Catlett said it's a wakeup call for anyone who takes their drinking water for granted.

"It's terrifying to think about it," Catlett said. "We all count on it, we're all so used to it. We're not ready for it really so we're all just going to have to do our best."

Crews worked Sunday night and Monday cleaning debris and monitoring water levels. General Manager Robert Stevenson says the system has been using clean water out of storage tanks. The tanks hold about 6,000,000 gallons of water and 1,000,000 gallons was lost during the incident. The city uses approximately 3,500,000 gallons of water per day.

Affected customers had been asked to conserve water in the following ways:

No washing of sidewalks, driveways, parking areas, tennis courts, patios, or other paved areas; no pumping of fountain recirculating water.

No filling or refilling swimming pools.

No noncommercial washing of motor vehicles, trailers or boats, except from a bucket.

No use of water for dust control.

No flushing of mains by PWSD #1 personnel, except to alleviate individual water quality problems.

No use of water from a hydrant, except for fighting fires, for human consumption, or for necessary watering of animals.

No watering of any lawn, garden, landscaped area, tree, shrub, or other plant, except from a hand-held hose or container, or drip irrigation system.

No eating establishment shall serve water otherwise than upon specific request.

Crews worked Sunday night and Monday cleaning debris and monitoring water levels. General Manager Robert Stevenson says the system has been using clean water out of storage tanks. The tanks hold about 6,000,000 gallons of water and 1,000,000 gallons was lost during the incident. The city uses approximately 3,500,000 gallons of water per day.

Affected customers had been asked to conserve water in the following ways:

No washing of sidewalks, driveways, parking areas, tennis courts, patios, or other paved areas; no pumping of fountain recirculating water.

No filling or refilling swimming pools.

No noncommercial washing of motor vehicles, trailers or boats, except from a bucket.

No use of water for dust control.

No flushing of mains by PWSD #1 personnel, except to alleviate individual water quality problems.

No use of water from a hydrant, except for fighting fires, for human consumption, or for necessary watering of animals.

No watering of any lawn, garden, landscaped area, tree, shrub, or other plant, except from a hand-held hose or container, or drip irrigation system.

No eating establishment shall serve water otherwise than upon specific request.

Boil Water Order Issued For Section OfDavie

June 23, 2014 12:42 PM
Filed Under: Davie, Davie Boil Water Advisory, Davie Water, Florida Turnpike, Old Griffin Road
(Source:Cate Gillon/Getty Images)
(Source:Cate Gillon/Getty Images)

DAVIE (CBSMiami) A precautionary Boil Water Advisory has been issued for a section of Davie.

Due to construction work east of the Florida Turnpike on Old Griffin Road a water main break occurred. Businesses and residents between State Road 7 west to the Florida Turnpike and from the New River Canal south to Stirling Road are under a precautionary boil water notice.

Those who live and work in the impacted area are advised that all water used for drinking, cooking, making ice, brushing teeth, or washing dishes be boiled. A rolling boil of one minute should be sufficient.

The water is just fine for bathing, laundry and irrigation. All fixtures should be run for several minutes to clear the lines.

Davie officials said the boil water notice will remain in effect until bacteriological testing shows it is safe to drink. The testing should take approximately 36-48 hours to complete.

<article class="content-single post-content post-area post-fi-content-top post-author-id-830 font-inherit post-106016 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-breaking-news category-news tag-barry-baker tag-boil-order tag-etna-green" id="post-106016">
<header class="page-header">
<h1 class="page-title entry-title title-single font-sans-serif">Etna Green Boil Order Lifted</h1>
<div class="entry-meta ">
<a href="http://www.inkfreenews.com/2014/06/20/etna-green-boil-order-lifted/" rel="bookmark" title="2:50 PM"><time class="entry-date" datetime="2014-06-20T14:50:49+00:00" pubdate="">June 20, 2014 2:50 PM</time></a> <span class="post-avatar post-avatar-tiny"> <img alt="avatar" class="avatar avatar-22 photo" height="22" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/c3e89a77eecca941717d38728e0d904b?s=22&d=identicon&r=g" srcset="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/c3e89a77eecca941717d38728e0d904b?s=44&d=identicon&r=g 2x" width="22"/></span><span class="author vcard by-author"><a class="url fn n" href="http://www.inkfreenews.com/author/alyssa-richardson/" rel="author" title="View all posts by Alyssa Richardson">Alyssa Richardson</a></span> <span class="entry-date-icon"></span>Updated: <span class="last-modified-timestamp">Jun 20, 2014 @ 2:56 PM</span></div>
</header>
<div class="entry-content clearfix">
<div style="float:none;margin:10px 0 10px 0;text-align:center;">
<span class="wvr-show-mobile">
<div class="mad">
<div id="div-gpt-ad-1478624825066-12" style="height:100px; width:320px;">
<script>
googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('div-gpt-ad-1478624825066-12'); });
</script>
</div></div>
</span>
<div class="size18" id="flags"><ul class="ui-sortable" id="sortable" style="float:left"><li id="English"><a class="notranslate flag en united-states" title="English"></a></li></ul></div><div id="google_language_translator"></div>
</div>
<div class="pf-content"><p>The boil order water advisory placed on Etna Green on Wednesday, June 18, has been lifted. According to the County Health Department, the distribution problem has been corrected.</p>
<p>Bacteriological samples have been collected from representative sites of the affected area for testing. These test results reportedly came back satisfactory and it is no longer necessary to boil water.</p>
<p>If you have any questions, please contact Barry Baker at 858-9321.</p>

<div style="float:right;margin:10px 0 10px 10px;">
<div style="z-index:5; float:right; margin:10px;"><script type="text/javascript"><!--

LATEST: All Eau Claire Co. beaches open after bacteria testing

Posted:

Eau Claire Co. (News Release) - Recent water testing by the City-County Health resulted in the opening of ALL Eau Claire County beaches and wading areas as all samples tested safe. These include Lake Altoona Beach, Big Falls Park, Coon Fork Park - both campground and dayside, and the Lake Eau Claire Beach.

*********************************************

Eau Claire Co. (News Release) - The Eau Claire City-County Health Department says water testing results show the water at Big Falls County Park and Coon Fork County Park dayside and campground is now within acceptable health standards and is therefore now open for wading.

Lake Altoona Park remains closed. The water will be retested today.

All other public beaches on Eau Claire County land are within acceptable standards and therefore open. Any questions regarding this matter can be directed to the City-County Health Department at 715-839-4718.

**********************************************

Eau Claire Co. (News Release) - The Eau Claire County Parks & Forest Department announces that water testing results by the City County Health Department indicate that Big Falls County Park, Coon Fork County Park dayside and campground beach and Lake Altoona Beach water is NOT within acceptable health standards and is therefore closed for wading/swimming.

Lake Eau Claire beach is currently within acceptable standards for swimming and therefore open.

The City-County Health Department policy is to close all areas whenever water samples indicate high levels of bacteria above safe standards. The Health Department will retest the areas on Monday and the Parks & Forest Department will inform the public when bacteria levels are within acceptable health standards.

Any questions regarding this matter can be directed to the City-County Health Department at 715-839-4718.

<article class="post-1458 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-news-to-you category-uncategorized tag-bacteria tag-beach-closed tag-conimicut-point tag-conimicut-point-beach tag-health-department tag-warwick tag-warwick-ri">
<header>
<h1 class="title entry-title">Conimicut Point Beach Closed, High Bacteria Count</h1> </header>
<div class="post-meta"><span class="small">By</span> <span class="author vcard"><span class="fn"><a href="https://warwickpost.com/author/rob-borkowski/" rel="author" title="Posts by Rob Borkowski">Rob Borkowski</a></span></span> <span class="small">on</span> <abbr class="date time published updated" title="2014-06-19T17:34:12-0500">June 19, 2014</abbr> <span class="small">in</span> <span class="categories"><a href="https://warwickpost.com/category/news-to-you/" title="View all items in News to You">News to You</a>, <a href="https://warwickpost.com/category/uncategorized/" title="View all items in Uncategorized">Uncategorized</a></span> </div>
<section class="entry">
<div class="wp-caption alignright" id="attachment_1007" style="width: 346px"><a href="http://warwickpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Health-Dept..gif"><img alt="Health Dept." class="wp-image-1007 size-medium" height="336" sizes="(max-width: 336px) 100vw, 336px" src="http://warwickpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Health-Dept.-336x336.gif" srcset="https://warwickpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Health-Dept.-336x336.gif 336w, https://warwickpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Health-Dept.-771x771.gif 771w" width="336"/></a><p class="wp-caption-text">The RI Department of Health has closed Conimicut Point and Newport Beaches for high bacteria counts.</p></div>
<p>Warwick, RI  The <a href="http://www.health.ri.gov/">RI Department of Health</a> has closed <a href="https://www.google.com/maps/preview?q=Conimicut+Point+Beach,+Warwick,+Rhode+Island,+02886">Conimicut Point Beach</a> and King Park Beach in Newport due to a high bacteria count.</p>
<p>The Department posted a news release and tweet announcing the closures Thursday afternoon.</p>
<p>[wpgmappity id=17]</p>
<div style="margin:5px auto; margin-bottom: 15px;"><broadstreet-zone keywords="not_home_page,not_landing_page,is_article_page,news-to-you,uncategorized,conimicut-point-beach-closed-high-bacteria-count" soft-keywords="true" zone-id="10210"></broadstreet-zone></div>
<p>Officials report the beaches areunsuitable for swimming, and they willcontinue monitoring water quality so they can notify the publiconcethe areas are safe for swimming again.</p>
<p>Warwick Post will update this story as more information becomes available.</p>
<p style="color: #222222;">For up-to-date information about swimming at Rhode Island beaches, call (401) 222-2751.</p><div class="apss-social-share apss-theme-4 clearfix">

<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<p> RENSSELAER  Customers of the City of Rensselaer water utility continue to be under a boil order following a main break on Wednesday afternoon.</p><p> As of Thursday, the earliest the boil order could end is 4 p.m. on Friday.</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset, atf","fold":"above","include_domain":null,"size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/newsbug.info\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/"}' style="display:none;"></div>
<div data-refreshable="true" data-region="fixed-big-ad-top-asset"><div class="tncms-region-ads" id="tncms-region-ads-fixed-big-ad-top-asset">
<div id="blox-ad-position-fixed-big-ad-top-asset1">
<script type="text/javascript">TNCMS.AdManager.render({region: 'fixed-big-ad-top-asset', slot: 1, fold: "above"});</script>
</div>
</div>
</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p> According to city officials, an 8-inch water main break occurred on the 500 block of N. McKinley Ave. Wednesday. That led to water being turned off at 3 p.m. for necessary repairs and the declaration of a boil order for a 48-hour time period.</p><p> The repairs were completed by water crews at 4 p.m. when the first water quality test was performed. According to officials another test was to be performed at 4 p.m. on Thursday and a third test on Friday at 4 p.m. Once the results are in from Fridays test, officials could lift the boil order. Officials said they will make an official announcement regarding the boil order following Fridays test.</p>

            $(window).load(function() {

                var bizTracked = [];
                var isUserAction = false;

                function trackActive(owl){
                    if( bizTracked.length == 10 ){
                        return;
                    }else{
                        var activeThings = $(owl).find('.owl-item.active');

                        $.each(activeThings, function(index, value){
                            var bizId = $(this).find('.card').data('bizid');
                            var hasBeenLogged = false;

                            bizTracked.forEach(function (item, index, array) {
                                if(item == bizId){
                                    hasBeenLogged = true;
                                    return true;
                                }
                            });
                            if( hasBeenLogged == false ){
                                bizTracked.push(bizId);
                                TNCMS.Tracking.addEvent({
                                    app: 'business',
                                    metric: 'block',
                                    id: bizId
                                });
                            }
                        });
                    }
                }

                window.card_carousel_1255932 = $('#block-1255932 .owl-carousel');

                

                card_carousel_1255932.owlCarousel({
                    loop:true,

                    dots:false,

                    autoHeight:false,

                        }
                    }
                });

                // bind previous click
                $('#block-1255932 .owl-carousel-control.prev').on(__tnt.client.clickEvent, function(e){
                    e.stopPropagation();
                    card_carousel_1255932.trigger('prev.owl.carousel');

                    isUserAction = true;
                    
                });

                // bind next click
                $('#block-1255932 .owl-carousel-control.next').on(__tnt.client.clickEvent, function(e){
                    e.stopPropagation();
                    card_carousel_1255932.trigger('next.owl.carousel');

                    isUserAction = true;
                    
                });

                // bind dragged
                card_carousel_1255932.on('dragged.owl.carousel', function(event){
                    isUserAction = true;
                    
                });

                // bind translated
                card_carousel_1255932.on('translated.owl.carousel', function(event){

            var $region = $('#tncms-region-asset_side_sticky');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&

            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');

                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 80;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 80) {
                                $region.css('top', null);

                });

    Boil Order Lifted for Wagoner Co. RWD #9 Customers

    by Juan Sanchez

    A boil order has been lifted Thursday afternoon for residents of a rural water district in Wagoner County.

    Officials with the Rural Water District #9 were notified that a water sample tested positive for E. Coli earlier this week. RWD #9 is located in Wagoner County southeast of Tulsa.

    KTUL was told that the sample tested positive at only one of RWD #9's testing sites. Officials retested the water Thursday and found no signs of E. Coli during two tests.

    Earlier this week The Oklahoma Department of Environmental Quality notified customers to use water that had been brought to a full, rolling boil for at least one minute or to consume bottled water or from another acceptable source for consumption, use in food preparation, dishwashing and brushing teeth.

    Officials flushed the system and chlorinated the water.

http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/Boil-water-order-in-Scotia-5562712.php

Boil-water advisory in Scotia

Updated 4:12pm, Thursday, June 19, 2014

SCOTIA Some village streets remain closed while a water main break is repaired, according to the State Department of Transportation.

Route 50 southbound was closed at Freemans Bridge Road due to emergency roadwork but has since reopened.

Delays still exist and some lanes continue to be closed on Route 5 westbound at Route 50 (North Ballston Avenue).

Parts of the village have been under a boil water order while the broken water main valve was replaced, Schenectady County officials said.

The advisory affects:

Mohawk Avenue (Route 5) from addresses 1 to 101 but excluding #32 and #40.

North Ballston Avenue (Route 50) addresses #104, #106 and #108

102 Glen Ave.

Water should be boiled for at least a minute and cooled before using for drinking, brushing teeth, washing dishes or preparing food.

The advisory is in effect until further notice. For more information, call 386-2818.
